Original_Text: LONDON (Reuters) - Oil prices climbed above $85 a barrel on Monday as supply disruptions in the Gulf of Mexico raised concerns about global crude availability.
DUBAI - A major oil producer announced plans to invest $3 billion in new drilling projects to boost output amid rising global demand.
NEW YORK (Reuters) - The dollar weakened against the euro as surging oil prices fueled inflation fears, prompting investors to seek safer assets.
MOSCOW - Russia's largest oil company faced new tax claims, threatening its financial stability and raising fears of asset sales.
SINGAPORE (Dow Jones) - Asian markets dipped as high oil prices weighed on investor sentiment, impacting export-driven economies.
HOUSTON - A breakthrough in lipid-based biofuels was reported by a U.S. energy firm, promising a sustainable alternative to traditional oil.
TOKYO (Reuters) - Japan's Nikkei index fell 1.2 percent as rising oil costs dampened corporate profit outlooks for manufacturers.
BRUSSELS - The European Union imposed sanctions on an oil-producing nation, citing environmental concerns over lipid extraction methods.
CHICAGO (Reuters) - A major agricultural firm reported a 20 percent profit increase, driven by demand for lipid-based products in food processing.
RIYADH - Saudi Arabia signaled it may increase oil production to stabilize global markets, easing fears of supply shortages.
